summary: Email chain between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the transfer and processing of electronic evidence from search warrants executed in the Epstein case. The discussion focuses on obtaining a 1TB hard drive to transfer a large volume of emails and other data from Epstein's New York residence and mentions pending processing of materials from 'the island' (Little St. James).

persons.name: Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI contractor communicating about generating load files and transferring electronic evidence from Epstein search warrants, including materials from the New York residence and the island.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: Prosecutor from SDNY following up on the status of electronic evidence processing from Epstein search warrants, expressing concern about timing and inquiring about materials from both the New York residence and the island.

connections.description: Communicating about the technical transfer and processing of electronic evidence in the Epstein investigation for legal proceedings.

events.title: Email coordination for evidence transfer
events.description: Email exchange regarding obtaining a 1TB hard drive to transfer a large volume of electronic evidence (primarily emails) from FBI to SDNY for loading into Relativity review platform.

events.title: Anticipated completion of New York residence evidence processing
events.description: Previously anticipated completion in late October for processing electronic evidence from search of Epstein's New York residence, involving 5-6 iMacs and 5 laptop computers.

locations: the island (Little St. James, US Virgin Islands)
keyFacts: The FBI had a large volume of electronic evidence from Epstein search warrants, primarily emails, requiring a 1TB hard drive for transfer to the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Evidence processing from Epstein's New York residence search involved approximately 5-6 iMacs and 5 laptop computers, with completion anticipated in late October 2019.
Materials from 'the island' (Little St. James) were noted as not yet started or still being preliminarily checked, specifically mentioning an 'Island DVR system'.
The email indicates the evidence processing was a 'long and complex process' requiring the development of a new procedure by the FBI forensic examiner.
